Merge pull request #2474 from NetChris/response_type_order_unimportant

Allow for response_type values in the authorize request to come in in any order.
use public origin for redirect back to permissions page #2473

Allow for response_type values in the authorize request to come in in any order.
This is required by the OAuth spec (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-3.1.1):
'Extension response types MAY contain a space-delimited (%x20) list of values, where the order of values does not matter (e.g., response type "a b" is the same as "b a").'

Add support for "private_key_jwt" client authentication method

Remove token replay cache

It is optional according to the specification, so as discussed with @leastprivilege, we can enable it back using streamlined cache implementation in next major version
Fix expiration date check in PrivateKeyJwtSecretValidator
Make thumbprint comparison in PrivateKeyJwtSecretValidator consistent with X509CertificateThumbprintSecretValidator

Add subject claim check in "private_key_jwt" authentication token

Subject claim must be set to "client_id" according to the specification

Add support for "private_key_jwt" client authentication method

This authentication method is defined in OpenId Connect 1.0 specification.
It enables simpler authentication method based on asymmetric keys compared to TLS client certificates.
Initially only "x5t" and "x5c" keys are supported, but other JWK key type support could be added later.

Merge pull request #1572 from IdentityServer/MultipleCustomGrantValidators

Added support for adding multiple custom grant validators
Added support for adding multiple custom grant validators

Preserves the primary sign-in cookie on a partial sign-in

Preserves the primary sign-in cookie on a partial sign-in because
 - A new "complete" sign-in was not performed so the last one should remain active
 - The access to the current sign-in is useful to enable the following scenario
   1. User is already signed-in on IdSrv
   2. User forces a new authentication flow (e.g by using "prompt=login")
   3. User uses a new external IdP
   4. On the callback, the UserManager service detects that the external id is not connected to any account and redirect to a "connect" resource
   5. The "connect" resource uses the current (preserved) primary id and the external id to ask the user if she wants to connect the external id to her account.

This change is to pass this back to the client.

Fixes #125 - Avoid double-prompting on initial login

Previously if prompt=login was passed for the authorize request and the
end user was not currently authenticated with IdSrv3 they would be asked
for a username and password, twice, before being redirected back to the
client.

Now they will only be challenged once, in both the 'user is currently
authenticated' and the 'user is not current authenticated' cases.
